abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the Northern
            Health Program Project is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as likely, institutional development impact
            as modest, bank performance as satisfactory, and borrower
            performance as satisfactory. A major achievement of the
            project was strengthening NGO-government partnerships in
            primary health care. Lessons learned include the following:
            Key partner NGOs with proven competencies were identified
            early and were fully involved in the design phase.
            Government ownership is also fundamental to sustainability
            of NGO involvement. The experience of the participatory
            component underlines the need to pay greater attention to
            practical difficulties in operationalizing community
            involvement in planning, supervision, and monitoring of
            government health services. The limited success achieved in
            the in-service training program is partly attributable to
            the culture of planning in the country whereby completion of
            physical infrastructure precedes recruitment of staff and
            other related inputs. As a result, software components are
            often delayed or compressed at a late stage of the project.
            A critical lesson learned was the need to involve the
            Ministries of Finance and Planning during preparation which
            is particularly important from the perspective of
            sustainability of recurrent costs. Careful assessment of
            financial management capacity of implementing agencies needs
            to be undertaken during project preparation.
